features.popup:
🎨 Pleito (CA-KER-77) — Polychrome Masterwork

Polychrome Pictographs — K-locale · Hulkuhku / Emigdiano Chumash
The crown jewel of Hulkuhku rock art and one of the most elaborate polychrome pictograph sites in North America. Bisected by a perennial creek in rich oak woodland, the site has 6 pictograph locales with extraordinary multi-colored paintings. Grasse's (2003) excavations revealed deep midden deposits of Late Period and Historical date immediately adjacent to and in view of the pictographs. Robinson's (2010) GIS viewshed analysis showed that 3 stations with 37 BRMs, both middens, and the vast majority of the site were intervisible with the paintings and shelter apertures. Critically, the paths from BRM stations to the creek — essential for water leeching of acorn meal — route directly past and through the pictograph viewsheds. There was no way to do the daily work of acorn processing without repeatedly encountering the painted surfaces. Reeves, Bury & Robinson (2009) demonstrated that the rare blue and green pigments came from locally available copper carbonate minerals (azurite/malachite) — suggesting the polychrome tradition predates European contact.
📊 GIS Landscape Data (Robinson 2010)
BRMs: 61 BRMs across 9 stations · 100+ cupules · 2 well-developed middens
Viewshed: 37 BRMs intervisible with pictographs · Both middens within visual envelope · Paths to creek pass directly through pictograph viewsheds
Sources: Robinson 2010; Grasse 2003, 2005; Reeves, Bury & Robinson 2009; Bury et al. 2003, 2004

🎨 Pond — Largest K-locale on the Preserve

Red Linear & Curvilinear Pictographs — K-locale · Hulkuhku / Emigdiano Chumash
The largest site on the Wind Wolves Preserve, covering approximately 300 × 270 meters within impressive linear sandstone formations overlooking a wide bowl-like valley containing a seasonal sag-pond. Five pictograph locales, all in red linear and curvilinear styles. Robinson's viewshed analysis demonstrated that 15 of 16 BRM stations with 128 individual BRMs are intervisible with the pictograph locations — the strongest visual integration of any mapped site. At the core of the site, the 'Window Box' outcrop with pictographs is visually prominent from the site boundaries, growing larger as people approached. Women returning to the same boulder throughout their lives to pound acorn would have worked under the constant visual presence of the paintings.
📊 GIS Landscape Data (Robinson 2010)
BRMs: Up to 132 BRMs across 16 stations · Dozens of cupules · Extensive midden
Viewshed: 128 BRMs and majority of midden intervisible with pictographs across 15 stations
Sources: Robinson 2010; Robinson 2006

🎨 Three Springs — Polychrome Cave with Blue Pigment

Polychrome Pictographs — K-locale · Hulkuhku / Emigdiano Chumash
Located next to a wetland area with three springs and a flowing stream. Two pictograph locales: one on the largest BRM station, the other a main cave containing complex polychrome compositions. Robinson's viewshed analysis showed almost all of the wetlands, 3 stations, and 27 BRMs are within the visual envelope. Notable for rare blue pigment — Reeves, Bury & Robinson (2009) used portable X-ray fluorescence to demonstrate the pigments derived from locally available copper carbonates. Chumash mythology specifically mentions 'blue-rock paint' in association with the Emigdiano people.
📊 GIS Landscape Data (Robinson 2010)
BRMs: 36 BRMs across 5 stations · Well-developed midden
Viewshed: 27 BRMs and 3 stations within visual envelope · Wetland area intervisible
Sources: Robinson 2010; Reeves, Bury & Robinson 2009

🎨 Santiago — The Monolith & Spring

Faded Red Curvilinear Pictographs — K-locale · Hulkuhku / Emigdiano Chumash
On an elevated terrace between a perennial creek and oak woodland. The core is a natural 'monolith' peppered with cupules, a BRM station, and three pictograph panels — all in faded red curvilinear — overlooking a spring and Santiago Creek. Sprague & Grasse (1999) documented large quantities of lithic flakes and debitage surrounding the Monolith. Robinson's viewshed analysis showed 7 stations with 30 BRMs intervisible with the pictographs. At Santiago, pictographs were painted directly on the same host-rock as the largest BRM station — food processing occurred literally on top of the art.
📊 GIS Landscape Data (Robinson 2010)
BRMs: 49 BRMs across 13 stations · 16 cupules
Viewshed: 7 stations with 30 BRMs intervisible with pictographs
Sources: Robinson 2010; Sprague & Grasse 1999

🎨 Los Lobos — Polychrome Shelters on the Ridge

Polychrome Pictographs — K-locale · Hulkuhku / Emigdiano Chumash
Well into the oak zone, on a mid-ridge slope near a spring. BRM stations are dispersed across level sandstone-shelf terraces. Surface midden with burnt bone and imported Temblor chert (Late Period point). Below the midden, sandstone formations contain two shelters with polychrome pictographs. The pounding of acorns at Station 3 would have thumped audibly into Shelter A beneath — a visceral connection between daily labor and the painted surfaces.
📊 GIS Landscape Data (Robinson 2010)
BRMs: 26 BRMs across 11 stations · 29+ cupules · Surface midden with burnt bone & imported Temblor chert
Viewshed: 4 stations with 5 BRMs intervisible with pictograph shelters
Sources: Robinson 2010; Robinson 2006

🎨 Chimney Springs — Oak Terrace Monolith

Red Curvilinear Pictographs — K-locale · Hulkuhku / Emigdiano Chumash
A grassy terrace surrounded by oaks, above a creek and near a spring. Two pictograph panels in red curvilinear style on a central sandstone monolith. The entire central area is within the cumulative viewshed of both panels — 6 stations with 17 BRMs intervisible. Asphaltum-covered rocks suggest basketry-making on-site; bunchgrasses and reeds provided raw material. Cooking activity also documented.
📊 GIS Landscape Data (Robinson 2010)
BRMs: 18 BRMs across 7 stations · 3 cupules
Viewshed: 6 stations with 17 BRMs within cumulative viewshed · Entire central area visible
Sources: Robinson 2010

🎨 Pinwheel Cave — Ridge-Crest Complex

Red Pictographs — K-locale · Hulkuhku / Emigdiano Chumash
The site with the greatest physical separation between BRMs and rock art of all K-locales mapped. BRM complex lines a ridge-crest with expansive views northwest. Oak woodland surrounds Pinwheel Cave to the south. Despite the distance, 6 stations with 12 BRMs remain intervisible. Robinson & Sturt (2008) confirmed Late Period and Historical occupation from midden directly under the pictographs.
📊 GIS Landscape Data (Robinson 2010)
BRMs: 19 BRMs across 8 stations · 12+ cupules
Viewshed: 6 stations with 12 BRMs intervisible with outcrop and Shelter 1
Sources: Robinson 2010; Robinson & Sturt 2008

🎨 Pebble — BRM K-locale with Pictographs

Pictographs — K-locale · Hulkuhku / Emigdiano Chumash
One of the named K-locales where pictographs and BRM stations share the same host-rock. Robinson documented that at 5 of 7 intensively mapped sites, paintings were on the same rock as the largest BRM station — the most-used food processing feature bearing the art.
📊 GIS Landscape Data (Robinson 2010)
BRMs: 18+ BRMs in immediate vicinity
Viewshed: Pictographs and BRMs share host-rock at largest station
Sources: Robinson 2010

🎨 Salt Creek Pictographs

Pictographs — Corridor Site · Hulkuhku / Emigdiano Chumash
Close to a number of BRM sites but not an independent K-locale. Positioned on a major internal corridor. Part of Robinson's finding that 15 of 17 pictograph sites are prominently positioned within the experienced Hulkuhku landscape.
📊 GIS Landscape Data (Robinson 2010)
BRMs: Near 8 BRM stations (18 BRMs + grinding slick)
Viewshed: Along major internal corridor of central Pleitito drainage
Sources: Robinson 2010

🎨 San Emigdio Isolate — Canyon Conduit

Single-Element Pictograph — Canyon Conduit · Hulkuhku / Emigdiano Chumash
A single-element pictograph on a conspicuous boulder along San Emigdio Canyon — one of three primary routes into Hulkuhku territory. Visible to anyone traveling the canyon, but isolated from the main K-locale network.
📊 GIS Landscape Data (Robinson 2010)
BRMs: None in immediate vicinity
Viewshed: On conspicuous boulder along major conduit of San Emigdio Canyon
Sources: Robinson 2010

🎨 Letter Cave

Pictographs — Near Pond K-locale · Hulkuhku / Emigdiano Chumash
One of three pictograph sites (with Lizard Cave and Echo) clustered near Pond. Together they sit in the densest archaeological zone on the Preserve.
📊 GIS Landscape Data (Robinson 2010)
BRMs: Within 1.5–3 km of Pond (largest BRM concentration)
Viewshed: Heart of highest site density · On central Pleitito corridor
Sources: Robinson 2010

🎨 Lizard Cave

Pictographs — Near Pond K-locale · Hulkuhku / Emigdiano Chumash
Part of the Letter–Lizard–Echo cluster, demonstrating rock art was positioned within the normal orbit of Hulkuhku land-use.
📊 GIS Landscape Data (Robinson 2010)
BRMs: Within 1.5–3 km of Pond
Viewshed: Clustered with Letter Cave and Echo
Sources: Robinson 2010

🎨 Echo

Pictographs — Near K-locale · Hulkuhku / Emigdiano Chumash
Less than a kilometer from a K-locale with 30 BRMs. Part of the Letter–Lizard–Echo cluster.
📊 GIS Landscape Data (Robinson 2010)
BRMs: ~1 km downstream from K-locale with 30 BRMs
Viewshed: Within dense site network of central Pleitito
Sources: Robinson 2010

🎨 Lost Canyon — Black-Linear Outlier

Black-Linear Pictographs — Outlier · Hulkuhku / Emigdiano Chumash (or earlier)
One of two sites outside the primary Hulkuhku land-use pattern. Exclusively black-linear pictographs — distinct from the red/polychrome styles. Robinson suggested these may be associated with different land-use practices and possibly different time periods.
📊 GIS Landscape Data (Robinson 2010)
BRMs: Outside primary areas of usage
Viewshed: May represent different land-use practices or time periods
Sources: Robinson 2010

🎨 Lonely Pine — Black-Linear Outlier

Black-Linear Pictographs — Outlier · Hulkuhku / Emigdiano Chumash (or earlier)
The second outlier site with exclusively black-linear pictographs. In more difficult terrain. Their exclusion from the main pattern actually strengthens Robinson's argument: the 15 sites within the normal pattern are all at K-locales, corridors, or pathways.
📊 GIS Landscape Data (Robinson 2010)
BRMs: Outside primary areas of usage
Viewshed: Difficult access area
Sources: Robinson 2010

🏘️ Matapuan

Ethnohistoric Hulkuhku Village · Wind Wolves Preserve
Western village near a major canyon mouth. Robinson found the closest pictograph site was almost 0.5 km away despite rock formations being present. This absence of art at villages is key: rock art was positioned at seasonal backcountry K-locales, not permanent settlements.
Sources: Robinson 2010; Merriam 1967; Kroeber 1925

🏘️ Tashlipun

Ethnohistoric Hulkuhku Village · Wind Wolves Preserve
Central village near San Emigdio Canyon mouth. The cost-surface path from Tashlipun to Chimney rock art site passes through or near nine archaeological sites, including Pond — showing how tightly pictographs were integrated into internal movement networks.
Sources: Robinson 2010; Merriam 1967; Kroeber 1925

🏘️ Tecuya

Ethnohistoric Hulkuhku Village · Wind Wolves Preserve
Eastern village at Grapevine Canyon. Especially high BRM concentrations nearby, but Robinson identified it as a political center rather than acorn gathering site. Anchored the southeast approach connecting Hulkuhku to southerly Chumash communities.
Sources: Robinson 2010; Merriam 1967; Kroeber 1925

Hulkuhku / Emigdiano Chumash Territory

San Emigdio Hills · Wind Wolves Preserve · Kern County, CA
The interior Chumash group documented as hulkuhku or Hool'-koo-koo by Merriam (1967). The term kuhku means "people" in some Chumash dialects; Hulkuhku is an external designation meaning roughly "over there people." "Emigdiano" is a Spanish appellation — Robinson uses the Indigenous term.

Territory at the convergence of the Transverse Ranges, Coast Ranges, Sierra Mountains, and Western Mojave. Robinson's survey documented 106 sites: 70 (66%) had bedrock mortars. 17 pictograph sites found.

Key finding: Pictographs were not at villages, not on external routes, but integrated into the internal seasonal landscape — at K-locales where the most important subsistence activity of the yearly round took place.
🔬 Robinson's Three-Scale Analysis
1. At villages? No — no pictographs at Matapuan, Tashlipun, or Tecuya
2. On external routes? Only 2 of 17 on major conduits — not boundary markers
3. In internal movement? Yes — 15 of 17 integrated into daily landscape

Seasonal round: Winter villages → dispersal → acorn harvest → K-locale aggregation → return
Sources: Robinson 2010; Merriam 1967; Kroeber 1925

🛤️ Santiago Canyon Corridor

Western approach. GIS cost-surface routes from the southwest (Quatal Canyon) converge through Santiago. Modern Preserve roads follow this traditional corridor.
Sources: Robinson 2010; Horne 1981; Johnson 1978, 2000

🛤️ San Emigdio Canyon Corridor

Central approach. The San Emigdio isolate pictograph sits conspicuously along this route. Routes from the south (Lockwood Valley) converge here.
Sources: Robinson 2010; Horne 1981; Johnson 1978, 2000

🛤️ Grapevine Canyon Corridor

Southeast approach connecting to the Tejon area and Ventureño Chumash territories beyond.
Sources: Robinson 2010; Horne 1981; Johnson 1978, 2000

📖 Coso Petroglyphs — Competing Interpretations

Bighorn Sheep Symbolism Debate · Three Major Hypotheses
The Coso Range's 100,000+ petroglyphs — dominated by bighorn sheep imagery — have generated one of the most important interpretive debates in North American rock art studies:
1. Hunting Cult (Heizer & Baumhoff 1962; Grant 1968)
Heizer & Baumhoff proposed petroglyphs were rituals to ensure successful hunts. Grant extended this into a formalized bighorn sheep hunting cult (ca. A.D. 300–1000) with ceremonial practices and communal hunts. His termination date was admittedly arbitrary.
2. Masculine Symbolism (Whitley 1982)
Whitley analyzed Western Shoshone origin myths from 12 regional groups (Lowie 1909; Steward 1936, 1943). In these myths, Coyote must kill a bighorn sheep and use its neckbone as a phallic implement to overcome a "toothed vagina" obstacle and populate the world. Coyote had already proven himself a capable provider, but only killing bighorn sheep gave the power for male virility.

Whitley argued bighorn sheep = generalized symbol of male success in hunting and sexual domains, not a formal cult. Supporting evidence: (1) Steward noted no ceremonial remnants in the Coso region; (2) geographic distribution of the myth matches Great Basin rock art distribution; (3) sheep imagery continued into the historic period (horses, wheeled carts); (4) excavations at 5 Coso sites found little or no sheep hunting evidence.
3. Shamanic Vision Quest (Whitley 1998, 2000)
In later work, Whitley proposed petroglyphs were created by shamans during altered states of consciousness, with bighorn sheep as spirit helpers and pattern-bodied anthropomorphs as the shaman's transformed trance body. Influential but contested — Quinlan (2000a, 2000b) criticized over-reliance on neuropsychological universals.
Methodological Note
Whitley (1982) advocated an "iconographical" approach (following Panofsky) relating motifs to broad symbolic themes across groups, rather than matching specific myths to specific sites. The persistence of oral traditions over millennia and the myth's distribution across 12 Great Basin groups suggest bighorn sheep symbolism operated at a deep cultural level.
Sources: Heizer & Baumhoff 1962; Grant 1968, 1980; Whitley 1982, 1998, 2000; Lowie 1909; Steward 1936, 1943; Quinlan 2000a, 2000b

🔬 Robinson 2010: "Land Use, Land Ideology"

American Antiquity 75(4):792–818 · GIS Landscape Analysis
Robinson's GIS analysis produced a landmark finding: pictographs were not private shamanic retreats but were deeply integrated into the most economically important places. The art was at K-locales where multiple family groups reconvened for intensive acorn processing. Viewshed analyses of 7 sites: 256 individual BRMs across 44 stations intervisible with pictographs. At 5 of 7 sites, paintings were on the same rock as the largest BRM station.
👩 Women, Labor & Ideological Media
California ethnography associates BRM stations with women's labor — women prepared acorns and sometimes held personal ownership of stations (Jackson 1991). During the autumnal harvest, virtually the entire population would have been at these K-locales. Robinson concluded subsistence and symbolic practices were conjoined at the most important economic places — an ideology linked to the control of resources and labor.
🗺️ Challenging Whitley's "Private Shamanic" Model
Whitley (2000a) argued rock art sites were shamans' private cache sites avoided by the public. Robinson's evidence directly contradicts this: the art was at the most public, most frequented economic sites. Pendergraft (2007) found similar patterns in the Great Basin.
Sources: Robinson 2010; Jackson 1984, 1991; Whitley 2000a; Quinlan & Woody 2003; Pendergraft 2007; Ingold 1993
